title: Problem with Abyssal Scepter update: It's still bad on long-range mages because of the aura
body:
Any long-range mage who might want to use Abyssal Scepter essentially wastes a huge portion of it because they can't safely use its aura. If they're close enough to use the aura, they're probably going to die because they're not being safe.

I question why it's still kept as an aura instead of applying a debuff on dealing spell-based magic damage that lowers enemy MR.

replies.body: Okay? I don't see the issue. Mana items are bad on manaless champions because it's a wasted stat...

Abyssal scepter is generally made for long range mages however, it is most often bought currently for when you want to be able to 1v1 better in lane mid lane. It has other uses of course but this is the most relevant one.

Mana items however are not made for manaless champions.

This is a problem because this aura range makes it bad on the champions who should make the most use out of it.

Abyssal Sceptor's designed to be an item for short-medium range magic damage dealers, offering them a mixture of the ability to survive in the middle of a fight and an aura that rewards them for being there. There's some tension there for some champions as to whether or not they should take it, with their team's composition and how they expect the game to go major factors in whether or not it's worth them picking it up. That's something we think's valuable, since it offers a game understanding check that doesn't have a constant right answer, unlike many other item options. A version made for long range mages by contrast would instead likely just end up as a must buy, offering both stronger poke and resistance to both enemy poke and all ins. 

TLDR: Range restriction makes whether or not to get Abyssal a game dependent choice on many champions.
So... in other words, a Lux can't get high MR without getting shot in the foot somewhere down the line, right?

Really long range champions will pay a price for that range. Some of that price will be that they won't always get the same degree of power from defensive itemization.

Or, if you were just interested in talking about Lux specifically, then no, Lux doesn't drive all our AP item decisions and does have to follow the same principles that apply to similar champions.

I feel like the real question being asked here is, why isn't there a MR option for mages that can't use abyssal effectively?  Not a different abyssal, something entirely independent.  Are our gameplay options A) have no MR and die or B) be forced to take a suboptimal item? 

You could argue that mages can build {{item:3026}} , but AD Champions are allowed {{item:3155}}, which fits seamlessly into almost any AD champion's build.  Why should one class be forced to build class neutral items and forsake their progression when other classes have multiple options that fit right in there? {{item:3156}} {{item:3139}} 

There has also been no MR + mana item since banshee's veil.  This rework seemed like an optimal time to introduce an item that could help both siege mages and mana tanks. {{champion:27}} {{champion:53}}. 

Why are you guys being so light on items for the mage rework?  AD Champs got 3 new items (4 if you count both LWs) and a number of items reworked into viability.  For mages you're giving 2 items and taking 2 away ({{item:3174}} {{item:3152}} ).   It doesn't really feel like their itemization is being refreshed like the juggernaut/adc reworks accomplished.

That's a terrible philosophy.  "We can't strategically balance the downsides of your long range kit so you just don't get choices as other champs".

There's already plenty of downside to playing a mana hungry, immobile mage that needs more time to scale than {{champion:238}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:1}}

Yes, there are already plenty of non-MR defensive options for them. They don't always synergize perfectly with all of these items _either_.

By the same token, long-range mages are perfectly capable of building MR items including Abyssal Scepter. They just have to be willing to accept the trade offs inherent in the choice.

Also, Athene's wasn't deleted. Sure, it's not the same item for the same niche, but only WotA was flat out cut.
